prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spectral imaging of W0134-2607 in CO(4-3)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Imaging CO(4-3) emission and surrounding continuum in ultraluminous hot dusty galaxy.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As our first "Justification text", we include more details here than in the other following ones, although our rationale is similar in each.
We expect our sources to have emission extending over about 2 square arcseconds (Fig 2), and specify a 0.6" resolution in each science goal in order to resolve emission into up to 10 independent beams on this scale, providing information about spatial structure.
Our Band-4 observations can be executed in configuration C34-6 and our Band-6 observations in configuration C34-5.
We aim one baseband at the target line, and use the other three basebands to sample continuum.
The predicted continuum and line properties are based upon the Herschel flux for W0134, extrapolated to longer wavelengths. The net Herschel flux of W0134, at a comparable redshift to W1814, is 4 times that of W1814 (Eisenhardt et al. 2012).
IRAM PdB measurements of the net continuum flux of W1814 at 233GHz gives 1.3mJy (Blain et al. 2014), and thus, we expect 5mJy of continuum emission in our band-6 tuning on W0134, extrapolating to 1mJy at 146GHz.
We intend to reach a sensitivity of 0.1mJy in order to ensure a reliable continuum detection and give a good chance of detecting and resolving CO(4-3) both spatially and spectrally, which we expect to have a peak flux of about 7mJy, in a line width of 500km/s. This follows the `Eyelash' line spectral energy distribution (LSED) (Danielson et al. 2011).
We expect an area of up to about 2-square-arcseconds for the target, and a 500 km/s linewidth. With a total signal-to-noise ratio of 70 in the line, and 0.6-arcsec resolution, we should detect each of the ten pixels on the target at a useful significance, and allow a dynamical map to be made using the positions of the line centroid.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spectral imaging of W0134-2607 in CO(7-6)/CI
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral imaging of CO(7-6)/CI and surrounding continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
A separate baseband is used for each of the adjacent lines to ensure that both are centred at the correct wavelength. Two continuum basebands are set at higher frequencies to maximize the expected flux.
The predicted continuum and line properties are based upon the Herschel flux for W0134, extrapolated to longer wavelengths. We take the net Herchel flux of W0134 at a comparable redshift to be 4 times that of W1814 (Eisenhardt et al. 2012).
IRAM PdB measurements of the net continuum flux of W1814 at 233GHz gives 1.3mJy (Blain et al. 2014), and thus, we expect 5mJy of continuum emission in our band-6 tuning.
We intend to reach a sensitivity of 0.1mJy in order to ensure a reliable continuum detection and give a good chance of detecting CO(7-6) nd CI, which we expect to have a peak flux of about 5mJy, in a line width of 500km/s. This follows the `Eyelash' line spectral energy distribution (LSED) (Danielson et al. 2011).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spectral imaging of W0204-0506 in CO(4-3)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral imaging of CO(4-3) and surrounding continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We aim a baseband at the target line, and use the other three basebands to sample continuum.
The predicted continuum and line properties are based upon the Herschel flux for W0204, extrapolated to longer wavelengths. We take the net Herchel flux of W0204 at a comparable redshift to be about equal to that of W1814 (Eisenhardt et al. 2012).
IRAM PdB measurements of the net continuum flux of W1814 at 233GHz gives 1.3mJy (Blain et al. 2014), and thus, we expect 1mJy of continuum emission in our band-6 tuning, extrapolating to 0.25mJy at 147-160GHz.
We intend to reach a sensitivity of 0.1mJy in order to ensure a reliable continuum detection and give a good chance of detecting CO(4-3), which we expect to have a peak flux of about 2mJy, in a line width of 500km/s. This follows the `Eyelash' line spectral energy distribution (LSED) (Danielson et al. 2011).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spectral imaging of W0204-0506 in CO(7-6)/CI
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral imaging of CO(7-6)/CI and surrounding continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
A separate baseband is used for each of the adjacent lines to ensure that both are centred at the correct wavelength. Two continuum basebands are set at higher frequencies to maximize the expected flux.
The predicted continuum and line properties are based upon the Herschel flux for W0134, extrapolated to longer wavelengths. We take the net Herchel flux of W0134 at a comparable redshift to be 4 times that of W1814 (Eisenhardt et al. 2012).
IRAM PdB measurements of the net continuum flux of W1814 at 233GHz gives 1.3mJy (Blain et al. 2014), and thus, we expect 5mJy of continuum emission in our band-6 tuning, extrapolating to 1mJy at 146GHz.
We intend to reach a sensitivity of 0.1mJy in order to ensure a reliable continuum detection and give a good chance of detecting CO(7-6) nd CI, which we expect to have a peak flux of about 1.3mJy, in a line width of 500km/s. This follows the `Eyelash' line spectral energy distribution (LSED) (Danielson et al. 2011).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spectral imaging of W0226+0514 in CO(4-3)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral imaging in CO(4-3) and surrounding continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We aim a baseband at the target line, and use the other three basebands to sample continuum.
The predicted continuum and line properties are based upon the Herschel flux for W0226, extrapolated to longer wavelengths. We take the net Herchel flux of W0206 at a comparable redshift to be 3 times that of W1814 (Eisenhardt et al. 2012).
IRAM PdB measurements of the net continuum flux of W1814 at 233GHz gives 1.3mJy (Blain et al. 2014), and thus, we expect 4mJy of continuum emission in our band-6 tuning, extrapolating to 0.8mJy at 146GHz.
We intend to reach a sensitivity of 0.1mJy in order to ensure a reliable continuum detection and give a good chance of detecting CO(4-3), which we expect to have a peak flux of about 6mJy, in a line width of 500km/s. This follows the `Eyelash' line spectral energy distribution (LSED) (Danielson et al. 2011).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spectral imaging of W0226+0514 in CO(7-6)/CI
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral imaging in CO(7-6)/CI and surrounding continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
A separate baseband is used for each of the adjacent lines to ensure that both are centred at the correct wavelength. Two continuum basebands are set at higher frequencies to maximize the expected flux.
The predicted continuum and line properties are based upon the Herschel flux for W0226, extrapolated to longer wavelengths. We take the net Herchel flux of W0226 at a comparable redshift to be 3 times that of W1814 (Eisenhardt et al. 2012).
IRAM PdB measurements of the net continuum flux of W1814 at 233GHz gives 1.3mJy (Blain et al. 2014), and thus, we expect 4mJy of continuum emission in our band-6 tuning.
We intend to reach a sensitivity of 0.1mJy in order to ensure a reliable continuum detection and give a good chance of detecting CO(7-6) nd CI, which we expect to have a peak flux of about 4mJy, in a line width of 500km/s. This follows the `Eyelash' line spectral energy distribution (LSED) (Danielson et al. 2011).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The WISE mission has completed an all-sky mid-IR survey, and catalogued over 700 million objects. Based on colour selection it has been possible to highlight a population of very luminous infrared galaxies that typically contain powerful AGN. Herschel observations, and some ground-based submm data have confirmed that they have SEDs that are broadly consistent with QSO2 SEDs, and are among the most luminous galaxies and AGN known. There are about 1000 of these "HotDOG" WISE-selected galaxies around the sky, and 64 have both redshifts and Herschel SEDs. We select a subsample of 3 bright examples at z~2 to image using ALMA. At this redshift, AGN are at their peak of activity and feedback is thought to be changing in form, presumbly due to gas consumption. ALMA imaging will reveal the spatial extent and nature of the emission responsible for the extreme luminosities of these galaxies, which might be key to understanding the most extreme feedback processes at work over cosmic history.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2013.2.00576.S: Assef et al. Observations of the [CII] emission line in Hot-Dust Obscured Galaxies
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
